instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
Hi, this board came in dead. board pristine, just a bit of dust.
when magsafe plugged in, its taking 20v 0.03Amp which cycle to 0 amp every few sec.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 3.8v, but every few second cycling to 13v for a split second then back to 3.8v
is this some kind of mosfet or <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> problem ?
pp3v42 : 3.42v
i tried all port same behaviour.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: ppbus isnt shorted on either side, and has diode mode of 0.400 with fuse attached.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: Check for short on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: l7410 L7420 and l7430 is 2.5 ohm, is that normal? Other than that, theres no short on any other coil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
CPU has low values on its coils; you should compare readings with similar board.
Check for voltage pulse on all coils, at same time when <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> pulses to 13V.

Remove F7000 and check if get stable <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
ok somehow ppbus isnt cycling anymore,
but voltage doesnt go past s5.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.1v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
do you do this to make sure board receive signa to turn on ?
voltage 3.3v, when onoff shorted, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drop to 0.3v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: Now check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
while checking that, somehow mac improve itself..
voltage now is stuck at 20v 0.26amp, trackpad can click, but no brain
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0v.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.

threads.message:

regardless I use another bios but turn out exactly the same behaviour.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
so im using thermal cam and see that <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR> is heating up.
voltage is 3v.
i replaced <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7708</CAPACITOR> which is also heating up, but voltage is 6v now.
i use same donor board to replace it.
how can I control the voltage to 1v ? ( the good value )

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> is broken, replaced, now 1.05v at <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR>.
but still no <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message:
Did you really get 3V, next 6V at CPU core?
If yes, CPU is dead now; even if was for few seconds only.
I suppose it was a bad measurement only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: its a <SIGNAL>PPVCEDRAM_S0_REG_F</SIGNAL>, does it count as cpu core too ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead ppbus cycling.
threads.message: Is the power rail for the internal CPU EDRAM.
